| system_map =Mbta district.svg map_size =250 map_caption =MBTA Commuter Rail
| provides commuter service from Boston as far north as Newburyport and
| Haverhill, as far south as Wickford (Rhode Island), as far west as Fitchburg
| and Worcester, and as far east as Rockport and Greenbush. image =MBTA_F40PHM-
| 2C.JPG image_size =250 image_caption =A train idles in Route 128 Station on
| the Providence/Stoughton Line. marks =MBTA, MBTX locale =Eastern Massachusetts
| and Rhode Island start_year =1973 end_year =present operators =1986 to 2003
| (Amtrak), 2003-Present (MBCR) length = gauge = (Standard gauge) hq_city
| =Boston, MA, USA website =[http://mbta.com/ MBTA.com]

The 'MBTA Commuter Rail' system serves as the commuter rail arm of the
Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority's transportation coverage of Greater
Boston in the United States. It is operated under contract by the 'Massachusetts
Bay Commuter Railroad Company' (MBCR) a joint partnership of Veolia
Transportation, Bombardier Transportation, and Alternate Concepts, Inc. which is
a Boston-based firm. {{cite web
| title = Our partnerships publisher = Massachusetts Bay Commuter Railroad
| Company (MBCR) Co. date = 2009-02-02 url =
| http://www.mbcr.net/partnerships.html quote =The MBTA Board of Directors
| officially approved a new three-year contract with the Massachusetts Bay
| Commuter Railroad Co. to run the commuter rail.
}} [http://www.alternateconceptsinc.com/ Alternate Concepts Inc.] -
website The current operating contract expires in July 2013. {{cite web
| title =MBTA Exercises Option With MBCR For Commuter Rail Service, Launches New
| Customer-Focused Improvements publisher = MBTA date = 2010-01-06 url =
| http://www.mbta.com/about_the_mbta/news_events/?id=18672&month=&year= quote
| =MBTA extends MBCR contract another 2 years..
}}

The commuter rail system is the sixth-busiest commuter rail in the country,
after New York, Chicago, and Philadelphia area systems, and is about tied for
fifth-busiest with Philadelphia's SEPTA Regional Rail in terms of weekday
ridership. The line's characteristic purple-trimmed coaches run as far south as
North Kingstown, Rhode Island, and as far north as Newburyport and as far west
as Worcester, both in Massachusetts. The trains have two terminal stops in
BostonâSouth Station and North Stationâboth transportation hubs offering
connections to Amtrak, local bus and subway lines. As of Q1 of 2013, daily
weekday ridership was 127,500. American Public Transportation
Association, [http://www.apta.com/resources/statistics/Documents/Ridership/2013-q1-
ridership-APTA.pdf Commuter Rail Ridership Report], First Quarter 2013.
categories: Passenger rail transportation in Rhode Island
Standard gauge railways in the United States
